text: in Yola the last few weeks have felt
like a deliverance last month Boko Haram
were advancing towards this provincial
capital now
the Islamists are on the retreat and
some are beginning to return home the
fact that people feel confident enough
secure enough to go back to those towns
and villages that were until recently
occupied by Boko Haram to go back there
to cast a vote seems like a remarkable
turnaround but it's not the full story
all of these people are still displaced
they're still fighting going on where
they're from this extended family of
more than 30 has found refuge in a
half-finished building they fled their
homes last summer when Boko Haram came
rampaging through their village
nine-year-old abu bakr muhammad saw it
all with his own eyes Tanaka's cassia
Mouton is smiley and comparision outside
a mutiny the killings the headings the
torching of houses that he has on my
house for the past five years the
government has often appeared to care
little for the people of the northeast
but in the weeks leading up to the
election Nigeria's floundering military
seems finally to come to their aid
yesterday as they took back one key town
celebrations were tempered by the
horrors of what they found odd would you
write after the lift
human bodies littering everywhere but
with Boko Haram suddenly on the run
people are asking why did it take the
government so long many locals answer
simply corruption some officials use the
pretext of security to do a lot of
corrupt activities is a reason it's a
justification for for a lot of
activities to be to be done in the
northeast there's a widespread belief
that officials have deliberately allowed
the insurgency to flourish so they could
divert funds meant to fight Boko Haram
into their own pocket
look people make these allegations
without any proof and the issue of
course is that when you finish allenge
like taro the affected people will get
anxious they will talk about you know
money not being directed what they point
to is that is the tens of billions of
dollars have been spent on security and
over six years Boko Haram wasn't
defeated no this is not about money this
is about understanding the nature of
terror
the nature of terror is something that
people here understand only too well
both the main candidates in the
selection have promised to make security
a priority the question is will they
deliver on that once the voting is done
Gabriel gatehouse BBC News in Yola
